statement.text: A juxtarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is an aneurysm that extends to involve the aorta immediately inferior to the renal arteries, with an inadequate infrarenal aortic neck (typically less than 10-15mm) for standard infrarenal repair. The renal arteries themselves are not incorporated into the aneurysm sac, distinguishing this entity from pararenal and suprarenal aneurysms. This anatomic configuration requires either suprarenal aortic clamping for open repair or advanced endovascular techniques such as fenestrated endografts.
statement.formal: Juxtarenal AAA: Infrarenal aortic aneurysm with proximal neck <10-15mm below lowest renal artery, necessitating suprarenal clamping or fenestrated/branched endovascular repair.

explanation.intuition: Imagine needing to sew a patch onto a garden hose very close to a branch point. If you clamp the hose below the branch, you don't have enough healthy hose to work with. You must clamp above the branch, temporarily stopping flow to it. In juxtarenal AAA, the aneurysm comes so close to the renal arteries that surgeons must clamp above the kidneys, temporarily interrupting renal blood flow, which adds significant complexity and risk to the repair.
explanation.key_insight: The critical distinction lies in the infrarenal neck length. Standard EVAR requires at least 10-15mm of healthy aorta below the renals for adequate seal. When this length is insufficient, the procedure fundamentally changes from a relatively straightforward infrarenal repair to a complex suprarenal procedure with inherent renal ischemia risk.
explanation.technical_details: Infrarenal neck adequacy is assessed by multiple criteria: length (minimum 10-15mm), diameter (<28-32mm depending on device), angulation (<60° for most devices), circumferential thrombus (<2mm thickness), and shape (cylindrical preferred over conical). Juxtarenal anatomy may also include accessory renal arteries in up to 30% of patients, further complicating repair. Open repair requires suprarenal cross-clamping with deliberate renal ischemia, managed through cold crystalloid perfusion (4°C solution containing mannitol and furosemide), which extends safe ischemia time from approximately 25 minutes to over 45 minutes. Fenestrated EVAR (FEVAR) represents the modern endovascular solution, utilizing custom-manufactured grafts with fenestrations aligned with renal artery orifices, allowing maintained renal perfusion during and after deployment.
common_misconceptions: Juxtarenal and pararenal AAA are the same entity - pararenal involves the renal artery origins
All juxtarenal AAAs require open repair - fenestrated EVAR is now first-line in many centers
Suprarenal clamping always causes permanent renal injury - most patients have temporary dysfunction only
Neck angulation is unimportant if length is adequate - severe angulation can preclude endovascular repair

definitions_glossary.juxtarenal: Immediately adjacent to the renal arteries without involving their origins
definitions_glossary.pararenal: Aneurysm involving one or both renal artery origins
definitions_glossary.suprarenal: Aneurysm extending above both renal arteries
definitions_glossary.infrarenal_neck: The segment of normal aorta between the renal arteries and the aneurysm
definitions_glossary.fenestrated_EVAR: Endovascular repair using a graft with holes aligned to visceral vessel origins
definitions_glossary.cold_perfusion: Renal protection technique using chilled crystalloid solution during ischemia

presentation: Usually asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on imaging
May present with flank pain if rapidly expanding
Hydronephrosis possible from ureteral compression by aneurysm
Rarely, renal artery compromise causing renovascular hypertension

anatomic_criteria.renal_involvement: Renal artery origins NOT within aneurysm sac

diagnosis: CT angiography is the gold standard for operative planning
3D reconstruction essential for fenestrated EVAR planning
Centerline measurements for accurate neck assessment
Assessment of renal function (eGFR) and split renal function if concern

open_repair.reconstruction: Tube or bifurcated graft with reimplantation of accessories

fenestrated_EVAR.fenestrations: Aligned with renal arteries, ±celiac/SMA if needed
fenestrated_EVAR.advantages: Avoids renal ischemia, lower perioperative morbidity

chimney_snorkel.indication: Urgent cases where custom FEVAR unavailable

open_repair.long_term_survival: Comparable to infrarenal repair if survived perioperative period

definition.@value: Abdominal aortic aneurysm with inadequate infrarenal neck (<10-15mm) requiring suprarenal clamping or fenestrated endovascular repair

sources.citation: Society for Vascular Surgery clinical practice guidelines for the management of AAA. J Vasc Surg. 2018;67(1):2-77.e2.
Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy, 10th Edition, Chapter 71
European Society for Vascular Surgery (ESVS) 2019 Clinical Practice Guidelines on the Management of Abdominal Aorto-iliac Artery Aneurysms

learning_objectives: Define juxtarenal AAA using anatomic neck criteria
Distinguish juxtarenal from pararenal and suprarenal aneurysms
Understand the implications of suprarenal clamping on renal function
Compare open repair vs fenestrated EVAR for juxtarenal anatomy
Describe renal protection strategies during open repair
clinical_pearls: Hostile neck features: short (<15mm), angulated (>60°), thrombus (>2mm), conical shape
Cold renal perfusion (4°C) extends safe clamp time from 25 to >45 minutes
FEVAR eliminates renal ischemia but requires 6-12 weeks for custom manufacturing
30% of juxtarenal cases have accessory renal arteries requiring preservation
Suprarenal clamp time >30 minutes significantly increases AKI risk

medicalCode.description: Endovascular repair of visceral aorta with 2 or more visceral artery endoprostheses
